Award.AwardTitle: Assembly, Dynamics and Regulation of Chloroplast FtsZ

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
The division of chloroplasts is a critical process in photosynthetic eukaryotes. These organelles arose by endosymbiosis from a free-living cyanobacterium and inherited several of their division components from the cell division machinery in their prokaryotic ancestor. Foremost among these is FtsZ, a member of the FtsZ/tubulin superfamily of cytoskeletal proteins. FtsZ self-assembles into a central "Z ring" to initiate division of the cell or organelle and generate force for membrane constriction. A crucial difference between bacterial cell and chloroplast division systems is that the bacterial Z ring is composed of a single form of FtsZ that assembles as a homopolymer whereas the chloroplast Z ring is composed of two distinct forms of FtsZ called FtsZ1 and FtsZ2 that coassemble as a heteropolymer and function together in division of the organelle. The funded research will combine a series of complementary approaches to probe the mechanisms, dynamic properties and regulation of FtsZ1 and FtsZ2 assembly with the overall goal of advancing understanding of the functional and evolutionary significance of the involvement of two FtsZ types in chloroplast division. The experimental objectives are as follows: 1) Analyze the kinetics of FtsZ1 and FtsZ2 assembly separately and together to establish how assembly is nucleated and whether the assembly subunit is an FtsZ1/FtsZ2 heterodimer. These and other analyses will also be extended to related chloroplast FtsZ pairs from one red algal and one green algal species to expand the evolutionary scope of these studies. 2) Analyze force generation at different FtsZ1:FtsZ2 ratios using a novel liposome deformation assay recently developed for bacterial FtsZ, and use a similar system to reconstitute chloroplast Z rings inside liposomes. These experiments will reveal how heteropolymer formation affects chloroplast Z-ring assembly and constrictive force. 3) Analyze FtsZ1 and FtsZ2 assembly behavior and dynamics in a heterologous fission yeast system using fluorescence recovery after photobleaching as a powerful complement to in vitro and in vivo studies. 4) Use quantitative fluorescence microscopy with tagged, functional fusion proteins in Arabidopsis to investigate Z-ring composition and dynamics in vivo, including whether the FtsZ1:FtsZ2 ratio changes dynamically during Z-ring constriction or is regulated in concert with developmental changes in chloroplast division activity. 5) Initiate functional analysis of plant-specific regulators of chloroplast Z-ring assembly towards understanding how FtsZ self-assembly is controlled in chloroplasts.

Broader impacts
The research brings together the complementary expertise of the project leaders and their lab members. One group, at Michigan State University, studies FtsZ from chloroplasts using biochemical, genetic, and cell biological approaches in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana. The other group, at Duke University, studies FtsZ from E. coli and other bacteria using in vitro biochemical and biophysical approaches. Interaction among project personnel by email, video calling, and exchange visits will provide an interdisciplinary perspective that has the potential to catalyze new ideas and research directions. The new studies on algal FtsZs will lay the groundwork for understanding how chloroplast FtsZs have evolved in all photosynthetic eukaryotes. Since mitochondria, like chloroplasts, originated from a bacterial endosymbiont and some organisms retain FtsZ for mitochondrial division, the research will be relevant to understanding FtsZ evolution in mitochondria as well as chloroplasts. In addition, because the microtubule subunits alpha- and beta-tubulin evolved from FtsZ, the research on chloroplast FtsZ heteropolymers may be relevant to understanding evolution of the microtubule cytoskeleton. Finally, Arabidopsis ftsZ and other chloroplast division mutants will be exploited to develop a teaching module for undergraduate ecology students to explore natural selection on chloroplast division and morphology. This will encourage critical thinking on the connection between molecular events, cellular structure and population processes. The research will also provide training for undergraduates in biological research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

Photosynthesis in plants and algae is carried out by chloroplasts. In order for these organelles to be properly inherited during cell division and to increase their numbers during leaf growth, they must divide. Chloroplasts are descendants of free-living photosynthetic bacteria, from which they acquired not only the ability to perform photosynthesis, but also key components of their division machinery. The core of the division machinery in nearly all bacteria and chloroplasts is the self-assembling cytoskeletal protein FtsZ, which polymerizes into filaments that form a contractile ring, called the Z ring, at the middle of the cell or organelle. The Z ring generates part of the constrictive force required for division. A fundamental difference between bacterial and chloroplast division systems is that bacteria possess a single FtsZ whereas most photosynthetic eukaryotes possess two distinct types of FtsZ. Previous work from the PI’s laboratory had shown that the two FtsZ types in land plants coassemble in the Z ring and that both are required to drive chloroplast division. However, their distinct roles in the Z ring were unknown. Therefore, the overarching goal of this project was to gain new knowledge of how FtsZ pairs in different organisms function together in the division of chloroplasts.

This goal was achieved through collaborative research combining the PI’s expertise in chloroplast division and plant cell biology with the co-PI’s expertise in the biochemistry and dynamics of bacterial FtsZs. Experiments employing a heterologous yeast system, Schizosaccharomyces pombe, to study the intrinsic assembly and dynamic properties of the two FtsZs from the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana showed that one FtsZ imparts stability to coassembled FtsZ filaments while the other promotes filament remodeling (disassembly and reassembly), which is essential for Z-ring constriction. Extension of this work to chloroplast FtsZ pairs from a red alga and other organisms revealed conservation of these functional attributes across highly divergent taxa. In vitro studies on the purified red algal FtsZs using completely different approaches led to similar conclusions, and further indicated that the two red algal FtsZs are arranged randomly in coassembled filaments. Experiments in a second heterologous yeast system, Pichia pastoris, in which Z rings could be reconstituted, demonstrated that coassembly of the A. thaliana FtsZs accelerates Z-ring constriction. This combination of approaches and expertise uncovered important functional differences between the two chloroplast FtsZs and yielded significant new insight into how they cooperate in controlling chloroplast Z-ring dynamics and constriction. Specifically, the research provided strong evidence that one type of FtsZ establishes the primary structural framework of chloroplast Z rings while the other enhances Z-ring remodeling and dynamics to promote constriction during chloroplast division. A further outcome is the finding that these functions are conserved from red algae to land plants.

A secondary goal of the project was to initiate functional studies of two plant-specific regulators of chloroplast Z-ring assembly, ARC3 and ARC6. Studies in S. pombe revealed that ARC3 is a direct inhibitor of chloroplast FtsZ assembly, and contributed significantly to the discovery that ARC3 plays a critical role in preventing self-assembly of Z rings everywhere except at the middle of the chloroplast. Similar experiments on ARC6, which promotes FtsZ assembly, suggested that ARC6 may function in part by constraining FtsZ filament dynamics. 

Broader impacts:

An important outcome of this project was the professional development of undergraduates, graduate students and postdocs, which contributed to the expansion and diversity of human resources in the STEM sciences. Five undergraduate students, one a member of an underrepresented group, obtained experience in scientific research. One earned a coauthorship on a peer-reviewed paper and obtained a position in a biotechnology company. Two are pursuing PhDs. Analysis of FtsZ dynamics and the two FtsZ assembly regulators in S. pombe constituted the Ph.D. thesis of a graduate student, who produced four first-author publications as a result of this research. Seven postdocs also participated in the research. All were either first authors or coauthors on resulting publications. Project personnel received training and gained valuable experience in scientific writing and presentation skills, collaborative research, and data management. Several postdocs and graduate students also acquired skills in teaching and mentoring through supervision of undergraduate researchers and participation in educational activities. Educational activities included development of a teaching module based on the PI’s work that introduced students in an ecology laboratory course to the interaction between genotype and phenotype in conferring fitness. Personnel in the PI’s laboratory also gained experience in scientific communication with the public through development of a hands-on activity for the Michigan State University Girl Scouts STEM Demo Day, which exposed girls from around the state to research on chloroplasts and the importance of plants for food and fuel production.
